title: The Plague of Locusts and Darkness
shortSummary: Exodus 10 recounts the continuation of God's judgment on Egypt through the plague of locusts and the plague of darkness, demonstrating His sovereign power over Pharaoh and the gods of Egypt. Despite Pharaoh's repeated pleas and temporary repentance, God hardens his heart to display His glory and fulfill His purpose in delivering Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: God’s appointed leader who confronts Pharaoh and delivers God's commands and warnings.

keyCharacters.name: Aaron
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ brother and spokesperson who assists in delivering God's messages to Pharaoh.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian king who repeatedly refuses to obey God’s command to release the Israelites, despite severe plagues.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh’s servants
keyCharacters.description: Advisors who recognize the destruction caused by the plagues and urge Pharaoh to let Israel go.

definitions.definition: A divine act where God strengthens Pharaoh’s stubbornness to fulfill His sovereign plan.
A devastating plague of insects that consume all vegetation, symbolizing God’s judgment on Egypt.
A supernatural calamity sent by God to demonstrate His power and compel Pharaoh to release Israel.
A supernatural darkness described as 'darkness which may be felt,' signifying God’s control over creation.

outline.heading: God’s Warning of the Locust Plague
outline.description: God instructs Moses to confront Pharaoh again, announcing the coming plague of locusts that will devastate Egypt’s land, demonstrating God’s power and judgment.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Partial Repentance and Restriction
outline.description: Pharaoh’s servants urge him to release Israel, and Pharaoh offers a limited release, but Moses insists on full obedience to God’s command.

outline.heading: The Locust Plague Devastates Egypt
outline.description: Moses stretches out his rod, and God sends a powerful east wind bringing locusts that consume all remaining vegetation, leaving Egypt desolate.

outline.heading: Pharaoh’s Plea and God’s Removal of the Locusts
outline.description: Pharaoh admits his sin and pleads for relief; God sends a strong west wind to remove the locusts, but Pharaoh’s heart remains hardened.

outline.heading: The Plague of Darkness and Pharaoh’s Final Refusal
outline.description: God sends a palpable darkness over Egypt for three days; Pharaoh offers partial release, but God hardens his heart again, setting the stage for the final plague.

application: Trust in God’s sovereign control even when circumstances seem harsh or confusing, knowing He works all things for His glory.
Obey God fully and promptly, as partial or reluctant obedience is not acceptable before Him.
Recognize the seriousness of resisting God’s commands, as hardened hearts lead to judgment and lost opportunities for repentance.
Pray for a softened heart and humility to submit to God’s will, especially in times of trial or conviction.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Moses, Go in unto Pharaoh: for I have hardened his heart, and the heart of his servants, that I might shew these my signs before him:
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals God’s sovereign purpose in hardening Pharaoh’s heart to display His power through the plagues.

keyVerses.text: For they covered the face of the whole earth, so that the land was darkened; and they did eat every herb of the land, and all the fruit of the trees which the hail had left: and there remained not any green thing in the trees, or in the herbs of the field, through all the land of Egypt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the total devastation caused by the locusts, underscoring God’s judgment on Egypt.

keyVerses.text: And the LORD said unto Moses, Stretch out thine hand toward heaven, that there may be darkness over the land of Egypt, even darkness which may be felt.
keyVerses.significance: This verse introduces the plague of darkness, showing God’s control over nature and His judgment on Egypt’s gods.

keyVerses.text: But the LORD hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he would not let them go.
keyVerses.significance: This verse confirms God’s sovereign role in Pharaoh’s stubbornness, emphasizing the divine purpose behind Pharaoh’s refusal.
